{"doc":{"info":{"calaisRequestID":"ec1a6f54-7f42-6e66-146f-22e789a1e00c","id":"http://id.opencalais.com/4KtLRrjipZZaY-ANr95mng","docId":"http://d.opencalais.com/dochash-1/9f1e4123-e02b-3b7d-86be-1b282e54f4a7","document":" ￼The trees here, though the wind leave off, never unbend. Likewise when he sat the stick retained The shape of the sixty years he had limped and leaned. He would haul from under the bed with the crook-end His bundle of photographs and the soldier\u2019s pay-book, The usual service medals and a card o/two in silk. The marriage bed was draped to the floor like a catafalque And he hauled the War from under it. And when he spoke Of the craters at Ypres he used the pool on Pool Green As measure, and the island\u2019s entablement of brambles when He spoke of the wire. He rose, drinking gin, Massive, straighter than his stick, and boys were shown At the hoisting of his trouser up the sunless calf A place that shrank like Lazarus from being raised, A flesh the iron seemed only lately to have bruised. And if one, being bidden and not in disbelief, Put in the hand to prove him right who That he was past hurt there\u2014probing In that still weeping place the fingers Wondering between them an angle of iron grit. For year by year his flesh, till he was dead, Evicted its shrapnel, as the living ground Puts out for the Parson or the Schoolmaster to find, Scouring at leisure, another arrow head. \n￼6. Spring Tide The summer moon was terrible. It beamed Like Christ on Lazarus. Nobody now, In daylight, can distinguish what he dreamed/ And what he saw, in night-clothes at the window. It was like All Souls when everything lost And the smothered dead struggle to rise. Around Midnight the moon hauled hand over fist £^sheet by sheet the waters were unwound. But nothing was recovered. Still the sand, That we saw white and phosphorescent, levels The slopes and pleasant laps of land And stops the doorways and the fires and wells. The curlews cried like springs starting to run. Then sleep began to fill us and we felt A weeping rise and flow. Now in the sun The sea is brimful and our cheeks are wet and salt. 34 \n￼w/c® ® o( 7. Sheer nowhere: the land Ends, the rocks pile dufnbly where they fell, And hold for any life nearer to ours than lichen There is none; the useful Wood of wrecks whitens beyond our reach. Rain passes, rain on the sea, and sweetens W ith all its copious fall by not one measurable jot the expanse of salt. Clinging to islands we Camping with our dead around a sunken plain Such as we are, late on, Want above all things passage to one another, Aid and the sharing of wells And not to swell our bitterness beyond The normal allocation of tears^ . 35 ","docTitle":"","docDate":"2014-07-01 09:47:50.922"},"meta":{"contentType":"text/raw","emVer":"7.1.1103.5","langIdVer":"DefaultLangId","processingVer":"CalaisJob01","submissionDate":"2014-07-01 09:47:50.298","submitterCode":"57b17a53-6e34-87b0-20ff-a419896f49c9","signature":"digestalg-1|GT5pYlpewvh4QvGgSXusc9WoZCs=|SIAhciI2Rd7QDKj9j6MdxbkjQuyR9eVe1Lz+ehg6HK0C0JAl2/pDRw==","language":"English"}},"http://d.opencalais.com/dochash-1/9f1e4123-e02b-3b7d-86be-1b282e54f4a7/lid/DefaultLangId":{"_typeGroup":"language","language":"http://d.opencalais.com/lid/DefaultLangId/English"},"http://d.opencalais.com/genericHasher-1/41ab1a04-532f-3d62-ae47-2149331a977e":{"_typeGroup":"entities","_type":"Position","name":"arrow head","_typeReference":"http://s.opencalais.com/1/type/em/e/Position","instances":[{"detection":"[to find, Scouring at leisure, another ]arrow head[. \n￼6.
